title: How to break down the song 'Bohemian Rhapsody?” What are its different parts? Is there a verse or a bridge - Quora

response.answer_text: Now, that is a question. Let’s look into this. We will have to do so without sheet music, because most of our readers don’t read, and I don’t have any Queen sheet music and am not going to buy any just to answer this. Bohemian Rhapsody is, to put it mildly, unconventional in form. It cannot be represented by any of the usual shorthands that we use to refer to song form in popular music. But it is as susceptible to analysis as any other piece of music that conforms to conventional Western harmony. It is 5 minutes 54 seconds long, at least the version of it that I have from the 1975 album A Night at the Opera. I am not aware of any alternative versions. Let’s go: THE INTRO 0.00–0.13: (‘Is this the real life’)—I hear this as a vi-II-V-I progression that lands on the tonic Bb on ‘escape from reality’. 0.14–0.21: piano enters (‘Open your eyes’), and here the harmony changes, going from the relative minor G minor to a dominant 7th chord on the tonic (‘Look up to the skies’) because we’re about to enter an area of harmonic instability. 0.22–0.31: transitional section (‘I’m just a poor boy’), ii-V, ending at ‘Because I’m…’ 0.32–0.38: this bit is something that no classical composer would do: the melody moves in sneaky little semitones above and then below the tonic. (‘Easy come, easy go’). But pay attention. Because this bit is going to come back in a big way. 0.39- 0.48: another transitional section (‘Any way the wind blows’), the harmony going from IV to a first inversion of I, then a first inversion of IIdom7, then a Vdom7. Why? Because of voice leading. We’re in Bb major right now, remember. The G-F-E-F movement mirrors the melody, the G being the mediant of the IV chord, the F being the dominant of the tonic chord, E being the mediant of the II chord. You can hear that E ringing out in the harmony of ‘Doesn’t really matter to meee…’ 0.49: the song gets going. THE POWER BALLAD So here’s the basic harmonic pattern of the verse in ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’. Upper case means major, lower case means minor. (I) Mama, just (vi) killed a man, put a (ii) gun against his head, pulled my trigger now he’s (V) dead, (I) Mama, life has (vi) just begun, but (ii) now I’ve gone and (IIb!) thrown it (I) all (V (F/A)) away, (transitioning stepwise down to:) (IV, except we’re now tonicizing E flat—treating it as, temporarily, the new key of the song—so really it feels like a new I, so let’s just go with that) Mama, oooo-oo-oo- (vi, which is now C) oooo, (ii, moving stepwise down to the new V which is B flat) Didn’t mean to make you cry, if (V) I’m not back again this time to- (I, moving down to vi) -morrow, carry on, carry on, cause (iv, oh the humanity!) nothing really matters. (1.43–1.48) transitional passage back to the actual tonic Bb, IV-I-Idim-ii-I. Then we have the same pattern again, in the next verse. Except, on the second run, it does something different. Because Freddie Mercury will not be confined by your song forms, hell no. We get to the bit where the song tonicizes E flat as predicted, on: (I) Mama, oooo-oo-oo- (vi) oooo, (ii, moving down to V) I don’t wanna die, I (V) sometimes wish I’d never been born at all… GUITAR SOLO The guitar solo is in E flat, and for most of its length it repeats the pattern we saw in the last part of the verse, except for: 2.56–3.02: by means of some exceptional cunning, instead of resolving back to B flat by way of all that voice leading the song has been teaching us to expect, the bass line on what would be I don’t wanna die part of the guitar solo proceeds stepwise from F-E-Eb-D to C#, holding on there just long enough to know that we’re off somewhere totally different now, because this C# is then repeated on a stepwise descent to a completely new tonic of A major, of which it is of course the mediant. THE OPERA BIT Whew! We have entered entirely new harmonic territory. But only for about eighteen seconds. Harmonic territory, yes, but not thematic. The very first item that is brought to our attention is; 3.06–3.08: (‘I see a little silhouetto of a man’) — this feels somehow vaguely familiar. Why? Because we last heard it two and a half minutes ago! Remember ‘Easy come, easy go, little high, little high, little low’? Exact same motif, but now it’s in a different key, and played faster, or as we like to put it in music theory, in diminution. (Thanks to Tom Serb for correcting my terminology,) No, this has nothing to do with diminished scales. It’s just music theory fucking with you. 3.09–3.12: (‘Scaramouche, Scaramouche, will you do the fandango?’) In strictly Schenkerian terms, this is really just three plagal cadences separated from each other by some superficial pissing about, but it still works. 3.12–3.15: (‘Thunderbolts and lightning, very very frightening me’) — this bit had me bamboozled for quite a while, because the voice leading consists of stepwise movement upwards towards the tonic A, which didn’t seem to make any sense and yet obviously it feels like it makes sense. It took a lot of listens and a shamefully long time for me to realise that in fact it makes sense in terms of an only slightly modified motion anticlockwise around the circle of fifths: III-VI-IIaug-V-I, or in chord terms, C#maj-F#maj-Baug-Emaj-Amaj. 3.16–3.19: (‘Galileo!’) Yeah, we’re at the ‘easy come, easy go’ motif again. It moves downwards to the V on ‘Figaro’, whereupon we get: 3:20–3.21: (‘Magnificoooo!’) Yeah—this is where Queen cheats, sort of, because this spectacular piece of vocal overdubbage is in Eb, arbitrarily shifting the key and distracting our attention from the fact that they’re doing so by means of vocal pyrotechnics. I mean, it’s pop music, they don’t have to obey the usual constraints. But this is the one point in the song where I, as a music theorist, see the cracks. 3.22–3.31 (‘I’m just a poor boy, nobody loves me’) This is that easy come, easy go motif yet again, but now it serves as a major structural pivot in the song, because this is where the song begins to move into one of the most epic examples of dominant prolongation in popular music: I mean the practice of holding off resolving to the key that you think of as the home one, by hanging on as long as possible to the dominant chord. In this case, I’m just a poor boy feels like it ought to be the tonic, until He’s just a poor boy, from a poor family hammers home its own assertion as the tonic by means of a plagal cadence and a transitional passage (3.32–3.34) back to the dominant B flat. 3.34–4.06: (‘Easy come, easy go’ up until ‘for meeeeeeeeee’) Okay, in analytical terms, all this Bismillah! carry-on, along with the shift to F major on the goo-oo-ooo-ooo-ooo and the subsequent bad-tempered stomp through B-A-D-C#-F#-Bb-Eb (‘No, no, no, no, no, no, no’) is just brilliantly conceived smoke and mirrors in aid of that dominant prolongation I was talking about. If you don’t believe me, start anticipating the return to E flat as early as the I’m just a poor boy mentioned above. I did this, this morning, while listening to the song and thinking about how I was going to write this answer, and the tension built up so much that when it finally returned to the tonic E flat at the beginning of the hard rock section, my right arm instinctively jerked as if I were hitting the riff on guitar. THE HARD ROCK BIT 4.07–4.14: Well, it seems to be in E flat, but this turns out to be yet another tonicization: when the riff moves up to F, we realise that the home key is in fact good old B flat. Or is it? 4.15–4.42: (‘So you think you can stop me and spit in my eyes’) Here again, the song exploits the ambiguity between two keys a perfect fourth apart, sometimes treating one of them as the tonic, at other times treating the other one as the tonic. But really, this bit isn’t about harmonic movement, it’s about timbre and pace and aggression. 4.45–4.54: by means of a transitional passage we move to B, then A flat, then B flat as yet another prolonged dominant—then we go to: THE POWER BALLAD (REPRISE) 4.55–5.11: We’re back to E flat, for a gently subsiding transitional passage that demonstrates once again this band’s gift for voice leading: Deacon’s bass in particular is doing double duty here in making the various chord changes make sense. 5.12–5.54: The coda. (‘Nothing really matters’) It’s a more developed version of the earlier iv-I Nothing really matters bit, only hitting the minor iv at 5.22. The piano takes up the earlier plagal cadences from three minutes in and immediately disrupts them with yet more of the line cliché voice leading, dropping down to a C major, which turns out to be the dominant of a final F major (‘Any way the wind blows…’.) Well, shit. The very first harmony in the song was G minor (‘Is this the real life?’). And by the magic of music, we have arrived at F major. In traditional analytical terms, the whole of ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ can be sketched out as an epic ii-V-I change. (Edit: Well, not really, because too much of the song takes place in B flat and E flat. But it does go to show just how much the song both obeys and flouts the conventions of classical harmony.) I hope you’ve enjoyed this little jaunt through the twists and turns of a song. ‘Bohemian Rhapsody’ is in many ways a daft song, but I think my analysis demonstrates some of the art that went into it. Happy listening.

The form of Bohemian Rhapsody? Curiously, it can be considered to be… a rhapsody! Rhapsody, from Greek rhaptein («to ensemble») and aidein («song »), ensembled song. A rhapsody is a musical work composed by different thematic segments joined freely and with no clear relation between all of them. Usually it begins with a slow dramatic part, followed by parts that increase the tempo and the overall movement. The rhythm of the parts can be different.
